title: Ted Needham
text:
Edward Needham (30 September 1872 – 26 October 1956) was an <a href="England">English</a>-born <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n politician. Born in <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, he was educated at <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a> schools before becoming a <a href="coal%20miner">coal miner</a> and shipyard worker. He migrated to Australia in 1900, becoming a <a href="boilermaker">boilermaker</a> in <a href="Fremantle%2C%20Western%20Australia">Fremantle</a>, <a href="Western%20Australia">Western Australia</a>. He was a <a href="trade%20union">union</a> and <a href="Australian%20Labor%20Party">Labor Party</a> official, and his sister married the future Labor <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Australia">Prime Minister of Australia</a>, <a href="John%20Curtin">John Curtin</a>.
In 1904, Needham was elected to the <a href="Western%20Australian%20Legislative%20Assembly">Western Australian Legislative Assembly</a> as the Labor member for <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Fremantle">Fremantle</a>, serving until 1905. In 1906, he was elected to the <a href="Australian%20Senate">Australian Senate</a> as a Labor Senator for Western Australia. He was the only one of Western Australia's six Labor senators to remain loyal to the party after the 1916 split over <a href="conscription">conscription</a>, and he lost his seat in 1919 as a result. Re-elected in 1922, his second Senate term lasted until his defeat in 1928, taking effect in 1929. In 1933, he returned to the Legislative Assembly as the member for <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20Perth">Perth</a>, shifting to <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20North%20Perth">North Perth</a> in 1950. He left the Assembly in 1953. Needham died in 1956. At the time of his death, he was the last surviving member of the 1907–1910 Senate.
